episodeTitle: The Fierce Fight Begins! Luffy vs. Hordy!
description: Hody Jones defeats Vander Decken IX and pursues Princess Shirahoshi with overwhelming underwater speed. Luffy intervenes using Gomu Gomu no Snake Shot to protect her. Meanwhile, Wadatsumi attacks the Straw Hats after receiving Energy Steroids, facing off against Jinbe and Sanji. Hyouzou undergoes a dramatic transformation after consuming excessive Energy Steroids and sets his sights on Robin, prompting Zoro to step up for a fight.

events.title: Hody Defeats Vander Decken IX
events.description: Hody Jones pulls his trident out of Vander Decken IX's body and, after a short confrontation, decisively defeats Decken. This marks the end of their uneasy alliance and Hody's claim of the trident as his weapon.
events.significance: Demonstrates Hody's ruthlessness and willingness to eliminate anyone in his path, including former allies. Sets up Hody as the sole primary antagonist of the arc.

events.title: Hody Pursues Shirahoshi
events.description: With Vander Decken defeated, Hody Jones turns his attention to Princess Shirahoshi. Using his overwhelming underwater speed, he cuts through Ryuboshi and Manboshi, reaches Shirahoshi, and grabs her by the hair, demonstrating his superior abilities in the water.
events.significance: Shows Hody's true power underwater and establishes the immediate threat to Shirahoshi. Forces Luffy to intervene despite being at a disadvantage in the ocean.

events.title: Gomu Gomu no Snake Shot
events.description: Luffy uses Gomu Gomu no Snake Shot for the first time, a post-timeskip technique that throws his arms in a meandering snake-like fashion before gripping the opponent's body tightly. He uses it to attack Hody Jones and force him to release Shirahoshi's hair, breaking one of Hody's ribs despite being underwater.
events.significance: First appearance of this technique. Demonstrates Luffy's ability to fight effectively underwater despite the disadvantages, showing his post-timeskip growth. Directly refutes Hody's claim that Luffy cannot protect anyone in the deep sea.

quotes.text: I spent the last two years training to do just that!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy's response to Hody's claim that he cannot protect Shirahoshi underwater

events.title: Wadatsumi Receives Energy Steroid
events.description: Wadatsumi loses his will to fight after Vander Decken abandons him, but Zeo deceives him and gives him an Energy Steroid. The steroid reinvigorates Wadatsumi, who begins a rampage at Gyoncorde Plaza.
events.significance: Demonstrates the manipulative tactics of the New Fish-Man Pirates and the dangerous spread of Energy Steroids. Sets up the Wadatsumi battle sequence.

events.title: Wadatsumi vs Surume
events.description: Energized by the Energy Steroid, Wadatsumi overpowers and defeats Surume, the giant kraken who had been helping the Straw Hats. This demonstrates Wadatsumi's increased strength.
events.significance: Shows the immediate power boost from Energy Steroids and removes Surume from the battle, forcing the Straw Hats to face Wadatsumi directly.

events.title: Fish-Man Karate: 7000 Brick Roundhouse Kick
events.description: Jinbe blocks Wadatsumi's massive fist using his Fish-Man Karate technique '7000 Brick Roundhouse Kick' (Nanasenmaigawara Mawashigeri). He stops the attack with his foot alone, hurting Wadatsumi's hand in the process despite the size difference.
events.significance: Demonstrates Jinbe's mastery of Fish-Man Karate and establishes him as a capable fighter against enormous opponents. Shows that technique can overcome raw size and power.

events.title: Sanji Joins the Fight Against Wadatsumi
events.description: When Wadatsumi falls and the shockwave blows everyone away, including Nami, Sanji becomes enraged. He kicks Wadatsumi in the head and declares that Wadatsumi will pay for hurting Nami, joining Jinbe in the battle.
events.significance: Establishes the two-on-one matchup of Sanji and Jinbe versus Wadatsumi. Shows Sanji's classic character trait of becoming more motivated when defending women.

events.title: Nuru's Debut and Challenge to Zoro
events.description: Nuru, an angler fish-man and anime-original character, appears at Gyoncorde Plaza. He declares his ambition to become an officer and the strongest swordsman of Fish-Man Island, challenging Roronoa Zoro to battle.
events.significance: Anime-original content that does not appear in the manga. Provides an additional opponent for Zoro before his main battle with Hyouzou. Character debut.

events.title: Zoro Defeats Nuru
events.description: Nuru attempts to blind Zoro with the lightbulb on his forehead, but Zoro easily dodges and cuts the lightbulb off, sending Nuru flying. Zoro dismisses him as weak.
events.significance: Demonstrates Zoro's superior swordsmanship and post-timeskip strength. Quick victory establishes that Zoro needs a more worthy opponent.

events.title: Hyouzou's Energy Steroid Transformation
events.description: Hyouzou, already drunk, consumes a large number of Energy Steroids. His appearance dramatically changes - his hair turns white and slicks back, similar to Hody's transformation. The combination of alcohol and steroids sends him into a wild, uncontrollable rampage.
events.significance: Major transformation showing the dangerous side effects of Energy Steroid overdose. Makes Hyouzou a much more formidable and unpredictable opponent. The anime shows this transformation more prominently than the manga.

events.title: Hyouzou Kills Nuru
events.description: In his drunken, steroid-fueled rampage, the transformed Hyouzou indiscriminately attacks anyone near him. He cuts down Nuru, the fish-man who was just defeated by Zoro, killing him on the spot.
events.significance: Demonstrates Hyouzou's complete loss of control and willingness to attack even his own allies. Establishes the lethal danger he poses in his transformed state.

events.title: Chidoriashi Hash
events.description: The transformed Hyouzou uses his technique Chidoriashi Hash (Plover Legs Hash) while on his rampage, cutting down several people indiscriminately with this multi-sword attack.
events.significance: First display of this particular technique. Shows Hyouzou's dangerous Eight Sword Style abilities while under the influence.

events.title: Hyouzou Targets Robin, Zoro Intervenes
events.description: The rampaging Hyouzou sets his sights on Nico Robin and charges at her. Roronoa Zoro appears and blocks the attack, cutting through Hyouzou's sword with his own blade. Zoro declares that he will take on Hyouzou.
events.significance: Establishes the matchup between Zoro and Hyouzou. Shows Zoro's protective nature toward his crew and his confidence in handling this opponent.

quotes.text: I'll be taking on Hyouzou. He'll be a good warmup for the New World.
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro volunteers to fight Hyouzou while protecting Robin

quotes.text: I spent the last two years training to do just that!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Responding to Hody's claim that Luffy cannot protect Shirahoshi underwater

quotes.text: I'll be taking on Hyouzou. He'll be a good warmup for the New World.
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro volunteers to fight the transformed Hyouzou

themes.description: The episode showcases the Straw Hats' improved abilities after their two-year training, with Luffy fighting effectively underwater and Zoro confidently taking on a powered-up opponent as 'warmup' for the New World.
themes.symbolism: The battles represent the crew's readiness for the challenges ahead in the New World, proving their training was not in vain.

themes.description: The Energy Steroids provide immediate power boosts but come with severe side effects, as seen in Hyouzou's loss of control and the physical transformations of users.
themes.symbolism: The steroids represent taking shortcuts to power, which leads to corruption and loss of self. This contrasts with the Straw Hats' earned strength through training.
culturalReferences: Substance abuse and loss of control

themes.description: Luffy's determination to protect Shirahoshi despite the underwater disadvantage, and the crew members stepping up to protect each other, demonstrates their bonds and resolve.
themes.symbolism: Overcoming environmental handicaps through sheer willpower and training.

themes.description: The Fish-Man Island arc, including this episode, explores themes of systemic racism and inherited prejudice through Hody Jones and the New Fish-Man Pirates.
themes.symbolism: Hody represents hatred without personal experience, learned from the environment rather than direct harm.

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy demonstrates his post-timeskip abilities and determination to protect others even in disadvantageous conditions. His training allows him to fight effectively underwater, something that would have been impossible before.
keyActions: Uses Gomu Gomu no Snake Shot for the first time
Breaks Hody's rib despite being underwater
quotes: I spent the last two years training to do just that!

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro shows his confidence and strength by easily defeating an anime-original opponent and volunteering to fight the transformed Hyouzou as 'warmup' for the New World, indicating his mindset for future battles.
keyActions: Blocks Hyouzou's attack and cuts his sword
Volunteers to fight Hyouzou to protect Robin
quotes: I'll be taking on Hyouzou. He'll be a good warmup for the New World.

characterSpotlights.development: Hody eliminates his former ally Vander Decken and demonstrates his overwhelming power underwater, establishing himself as the arc's main threat.
keyActions: Pursues Shirahoshi with incredible underwater speed

characterSpotlights.development: Hyouzou undergoes a dramatic transformation after overdosing on Energy Steroids while drunk, becoming a wild, uncontrollable force that attacks friend and foe alike.
keyActions: Goes on a rampage with Chidoriashi Hash
Targets Robin before being intercepted by Zoro

mangaDifferences.difference: The character Nuru is anime-original and does not appear in the manga. His entire subplot of challenging Zoro, being defeated, and then killed by Hyouzou is added content.
The anime extends Hody's pursuit of Shirahoshi compared to the manga, showing more detail of his underwater chase and the attacks on Ryuboshi and Manboshi.
Hyouzou's transformation from Energy Steroid overdose is shown more prominently and in greater detail in the anime than in the manga.

trivia.fact: Episode 560 adapts pages 2-19 of Chapter 639, making it a moderately paced adaptation covering most of one manga chapter.
This episode aired on August 19, 2012 in Japan but was simulcast on August 18, 2012 in the United States, meaning US viewers saw it one day before the Japanese broadcast date.
The opening theme 'We Go!' by Hiroshi Kitadani was described by the artist as 'a sort of response song to We Are!' (the original One Piece opening), both performed by the same artist.

sources.title: One Piece Opening 15: We Go! by Hiroshi Kitadani

trivia.fact: Episode 560 has no ending theme song, as One Piece stopped airing ending themes from episode 279 to episode 1070 (over 17 years) to allow for longer opening sequences.
The episode received a TV rating of 8.7% in Japan, ranking 5th for its time slot.
The IMDb rating for this episode is 7.3/10, slightly lower than the series average, likely due to the pacing issues common in the Fish-Man Island arc.
